participants.participant: David I. Thodey, Chief Executive Officer
John V. Stanhope, Chief Financial Officer and Group Managing Director, Finance and Administration

plist.p: 0MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

Good morning, everyone. My name is Ben Spincer, Director of Investor Relations at Telstra. I'd like to welcome you to this our 2010 financial results presentation. I should also welcome all those people on the phone and also watching the webcast this morning. I will hand over now to the CEO David Thodey who will give a brief introduction and then we will run though the results with David and John. Thank you.
Thanks Ben and let me also just add my welcome, great to have you here and also welcome everyone who is on the phone right around the world I do say.

Well let me begin, 2010 definitely was a tough year and we've faced many significant challenges, the NBN negotiations were long and protracted. We've seen quite a significant change in consumer behavior which we've sort of seen happening for a while but now has accelerated and of course we're seeing much tougher price competition. But despite those challenges the company has emerged stronger. We've seen renewed momentum in the last couple of months of the last half. We're seeing improvement, improving customer service and of course we have the preliminary agreement well on NBN.

Now in addition and we'll be talking about this in a moment, we've achieved our February operating guidance including the key target of $6 billion of free cash flow and we've seen really strong cost management right throughout the year. But of course these challenges haven't gone away and the whole industry faces many challenges that we're going to have to confront. Now as Ben said we're going to change the format a little bit this year. I'm going to ask John to come up and actually go through all the financial results then I'm going to come back later on and actually talk about the future. Think this might be a better structure for the morning.

But before we begin I do want to address a very important strategic decision that we need to make for this company. Today the greatest asset that Telstra has is our customer base and we have been losing too many customers. And we cannot allow it. In fact I'm not going to allow to continue. So we've got two strategic options we've got in front of us. Firstly, we could maximize our cash returns in the short term, cut costs and continue to lose market share or we could take a longer term view by investing and that's investing in customer service, simplifying the business and competing aggressively to retain and acquire customers. And of course to prepare for future opportunities.

Now we have looked at this in detail and we believe that it is in the best interest of shareholders to manage this business for the sustainable future growth of this company, not for the short term. So today we are going to announce some bold but necessary steps to drive profitable growth over the longer term. But I'm going to come back and talk about that later on. Let me now pass across to John who is going to take you through the results for last year. So John.

Thank you, David, and good morning to everyone here and everyone wherever you may be. Let me start by saying that in November 2005 we set a target of achieving $6 billion free cash flow and by 2010. This was obviously an extremely important target for us and our shareholders. How we achieve this target has evolved with the business and market over the last 5 years. But I am pleased to say that 5 years down the track we are there.

Now let me move on to the rest of the results, because that certainly is a highlight. As David mentioned, I am pleased to report this morning that we met our February guidance for the fiscal year 2010. And as I just said, we grew free cash flow by $1.9 billion to $6.2 billion this year. We maintained our $0.28 per share dividend for the full year and that's fully franked. All this despite the challenging market conditions we faced over the past year.

On our February guidance basis, so excluding the CSL impairment, we reported a sales revenue decline of 2.2% to $24.8 billion. Operating expenses continue to be tightly managed and fell by 4.5%. With this tight cost control EBITDA grew by 0.6% with margins growing 1.2 percentage points to 44.4%. EBIT grew by 1.7%, in line with our guidance of low single digit growth. Including the impairment of CSL, EBITDA declined by 0.9% and EBIT also declined by 0.9% and profit after-tax declined by 4.7%.

As always there are some adjustments that need to be made to our reported financial results to get a better representation of the underlying business performance. These adjustments are consistent with the adjustments we made at the half year so they take into account the sale of KAZ in the prior year the significant strengthening of the Australian dollar through the year, the fair value adjustments included in the finance cost plus of course the CSL impairment.

For the rest of this presentation therefore I'll be discussing the adjusted numbers. On an adjusted basis therefore the sales revenue declined by 0.2%, EBITDA grew by 1.3% and EBIT was up 2.4% and profit after tax up 7.6%. You can also see the improved performance in the second half, which was a key commitment we made at the half year with sales revenue growing 0.3%, EBITDA 2.4% and EBIT up 2.7%.

While I'm talking about high level numbers I'd just like to cover off the impairment charge at CSL. Telstra's investment in CSL is recorded in our financial statements in Australian dollars and a test of the investments carrying value is undertaken each half year using the A dollar forecast cash flows for the business. The forecast cash flows of CSL had been lowered to reflect the softer margins the business is likely to experience given the intensely competitive wireless market in Hong Kong and the lower '09, '10 base given the recent performance of the business. As such we booked a non-cash impairment against the goodwill of this investment of $168 million.

But looking forward we remain upbeat about the fiscal year '11 performance of CSL and we expect top line in the local currency to return to growth as the Hong Kong economy improves. And CSL takes advantage of the opportunity presented by the iPhone 4 and leveraging its network advantage. This will be the first time CSL has sold the iPhone and should assist the business to recapture the revenue market share.

In terms of performance from our products, it has been a challenging year. The PSTN revenue loss was significant however we are still seeing strong growth in the key areas of mobiles and IP products. For this fiscal year PSTN revenue declined 8% to $5.8 billion and fixed Internet declined by 0.7% to $2.1 billion. Mobiles was again strong, with total mobile revenue increasing 6.4%, an increase of $439 million. IP and data access was up 1.7% to $1.8 billion, however within this category IP access grew 24% to $835 million, leveraging off our wireline transformation. Of course the changing product mix means that margins also changed.

So before I discuss the product performance in more detail, I'd like to look at the profitability of those products. PSTN is clearly impacting our profitability, given the decline in revenue from that product. What is encouraging is that fixed broadband margins have improved as the broadband market has slowed and we achieve lower network unit cost from the economy of scales. Mobiles, IP and data, fixed broadband and Sensis have driven the greatest value in absolute EBITDA terms. However, the contribution from those products is being offset by the dilution in PSTN where the revenue decline is faster than the decline in costs.

These pie charts provide a summary of how Telstra's revenue and EBITDA mix has changed over the past year as well as highlighting just how diversified our portfolio of products is. Of particular note is a continued relative shift in the importance of mobiles and PSTN. PSTN's contribution to EBITDA has declined by 3 percentage points in the year, symptomatic of the structured decline in that product, while mobiles has increased by 2 percentage points. It is also worth noting the importance of Sensis to the business. It contributed 9% of revenue and 11% of total EBITDA.

Back to the performance of our products. Fixed retail broadband revenue grew by 0.9% to $1.5 billion however what is more pleasing is that our new pricing plans and bundles has seen the negative SIO trend experienced over the past 2 halves reverse in the second half of this fiscal year. 11,000 customers were added and we only saw a very minor reduction in ARPU in the 6 months to 30 June. In terms of IP access, the growth in IP access revenue of 23.5% offsets the decline in legacy specialized data and global products such as loose lines. Furthermore, as the penetration of IP applications grow, customer value also increases.

Sensis also achieved a solid improvement during the second half. This was achieved as Sensis continued to use next generation digital media products such as the T-Hub and iPhone to complement the more standard directories channels of print and online. In terms of financial performance, Sensis' domestic sales revenue declined by 2.3% in the second half, an improvement on the 3.6 decline in the first half.

In terms of mobiles, total mobile revenue grew by 6.4% to $7.3 billion, with service revenue increasing 5.9% to $6.5 billion. Again, second half momentum has improved with mobile service revenue growing by 7.1% compared to the 4.7% growth in the first half.

Where this growth is coming from is data. Data really is the mobile growth story. Telstra now has over 1.6 million wireless broadband customers and revenue generated in this area are increased by 34% to $787 million for the full year. The largest component of data revenue is still messaging, which grew by 14%. You can also see here how we have provided additional reporting of prepaid unique users. We believe unique users is a more representative and less volatile measure of our revenue generating prepaid customers.

Moving on to PSTN. On this chart we have attempted to deconstruct the $0.5 billion absolute decline in PSTN revenues in the past year and look at the drivers of that decline. I'd urge you to treat some of these numbers as indicative because we have made some assumptions around average users and the retail/wholesale split to get this on a single page, but there are some obvious conclusions. The PSTN decline is driven by a combination of line loss and usage decline. In terms of the line loss, about a third of the revenue has shifted to ULL with the rest loss to more than 200,000 net cancelations in the year. On usage there has been a decline in all core categories in the last year. Overall PSTN customers made nearly six fewer calls a month in 2010 than they made during 2009, with the decline in fixed mobile being the biggest driver. But we probably clawed back around a third of the ULL revenue decline in our wholesale division and ULL booked in our intercarrier access revenue line, we are also seeing – and that's where it appears in our financial statements that you have.

We are also seeing strong growth in our IP telephony products with some revenue shifting from PSTN to IP access. Finally, there is clearly significant mobile substitution occurring both in terms of the traffic moving to mobile and also an increase in mobile only households, which we now estimate is around about 12%. So if we look at this in terms of PSTN and PSTN substitution, there is still a decline but it's perhaps overall when you take all those movements into account, around 5 to 6%.

Before I move on to expenses I just want to discuss the performance of our retail business units. Telstra Consumer faced a very challenging year through the intensely competitive landscape. Sales revenue declined by 0.5%, however, significant initiatives such as the T-Hub, new bundles in pricing were implemented in the second half to address this performance. Around 41% of our consumer customers have 2 or more Telstra products and around 300,000 customers have signed up for our new bundled offer. Business returned to growth in the second half with sales revenue growing 2.3% after declining by 0.4% in the first half. In the second half Telstra business launched Mobile Plus pricing plans which incorporated both voice and data and as a result we have seen increased smartphone penetration and higher data ARPUs.

In the Enterprise and Government segment, revenue growth accelerated in the second half to 2.9%, with 0.3% growth in the first half. For the full year on an underlying basis, so excluding the sale of KAZ, sales revenue grew by 1.6% and significant contract wins during the year including Suncorp and Komatsu contributed to that outcome.

Now let me move on to expenses and a real, which is a real positive to come out of those results. Excluding the CSL impairment, operating expenses declined by $653 million or 4.5% this fiscal year. Variable costs as a percentage of sales has increased this year, but this is an important trend as this does reflect the product mix shift that I spoke about earlier and later you'll hear more about how that's continuing.

However, we continue to maintain a very tight control over our fixed costs which declined by 7.5% this year and that does exclude the CSL impairment. So looking more closely at where the cost savings were realized this year. Labor expense, adjusted for cash and FX movements, declined by 6.2%. The decline has been driven by fewer head count plus a lower salary and associated cost expense. Redundancy costs also declined due to the absence of, or lower redundancies than we had the prior year, redundancies associated with our marketing simplification program. Subscriber acquisition and retention costs or SARCs have increased. That is flagged at the half. This has been managed, been a managed increase to support the popularity of smartphones. While SARCs has increased, SARCs as percentage of mobile services revenue has increased by less than 1%.

One area of disappoint to us is in our cost base has been our bad debt expense. Bad debts did increase 44% to 364 million. Admittedly much of the increase was self inflicted with what we call bad volumes. Bad volumes includes sort of misalignment between the customer's choice of a plan and the plan they are initially billed for and the difficult economic times also contributed to the larger write off. So we had two elements, we had confusion by customers with plans and charges on their bills, et cetera. But we also did experience some bad debts due to the economic conditions. And pleasing though we know we've got a detailed remediation plan in place to make sure they are lower, we have lower bad debts moving forward. On a more positive note, there were large decreases in many categories of our discretionary costs including travel and our legal expenses.

Now let's have a quick look at depreciation and finance and tax. D&A came down – came in at $4.3 billion and adjusting for KAZ and the impacts of FX again D&A did decline by 0.3%. While the depreciation charge was lower due to the absence of the prior year's accelerated depreciation in CSL, amortization expense increased due to a full year of amortization of the Trading Post masthead, which we signaled we would do last time and that was about $67 million.

Borrowing costs also reduced this year by 11.7% or to just over $1 billion as the average volume of debt and the cost of servicing that debt is lower. Over the past 12 months net debt has reduced to $13.9 billion while our average borrowing costs on average debt was 6.4%.

Moving onto the tax and the all important franking credit balance, at the full year our franking account balance was in deficit to the tune of $138 million. However it is important to note that the tax payments we have made subsequent to 30 June will allows us to have sufficient franking credits to enable us to fully frank the final dividend of $0.14 per share. Looking forward, we expect the franking credit balance to remain tight for a number of years, while we do not believe this will constrain our ability to fully frank a dividend at current levels. It will constrain our ability to increase fully franked dividends should the board resolve to increase returns to shareholders.

Moving on to capital expenditure, operating capital expenditure declined by $1.1 billion to $3.5 billion. This represents 14% of sales so right in line our guidance. What is on the slide here is how we look at CapEx internally. So on an activity view rather than a technology view which is how we have disclosed CapEx in the past. But you'll find in both views in the documents that we've lodged and handed out today. As you can see, the largest component of our CapEx been this year was customer demand and customer experience. It accounted for 45% of our total CapEx program. Customer demand and experience CapEx, which did reduce by 404 million to 1.6 billion is focused on meeting our customer demand for existing products and services such as mobile base stations and spending on our fixed access networks. Whilst on fixed access CapEx, while I'm talking about that expenditure we would not have to bear with a fully rolled out NBN, would be around $300 million per annum.

Moving on to free cash flow, as I said earlier, we exceeded our target, generating $6.2 billion of free cash flow this fiscal year. The increase in free cash flow of the year came from obviously the reduced capital expenditure we had of $1.3 billion but also a one-off R&D tax refund of almost $250 million. As you can see from the slide, free cash flow has more than doubled over the last 3 years which has given us the headroom to make some investments to ensure future growth.

So before moving on to the last slide which is about guidance, I want to explain why we need to make an investment in the business in 2011 which results in the guidance that we are giving today. The pressures on the business are quite different from 5 years ago. While margins increased in fiscal 2010, it is because we delivered on our fixed cost reductions from the transformation as I went through earlier. In 2005, the transformation was an enabler for ongoing product and service differentiation and improvements in operations. 5 years on, the industry is at an inflexion point and Telstra in particular. With price competition being intense, fixed services being substituted by mobile services and product mix changes putting pressure on margins, we must prepare for this by structurally changing the company which will require some investment, mainly indirectly variable costs and an investment to deliver a lower cost operation and revenue growth in the longer term. David will tell you in his presentation what we are doing and how we are going about it.

So leads me to the guidance. We view 2011 as a transition year as we invest in operational excellence to prepare the company to compete in the future. We had made this decision to improve customer service and satisfaction, simplify our business and core processes and prepare the business for an NBN world by investing to grow new revenue streams that compensate for reductions in traditional fixed revenues.

So 2011, we expect an increase in the customer base with flattish revenue. But because of our investments and the changing product mix, the company expects high single digit percentage decline in EBITDA. We also expect free cash flow of somewhere between 4.5 and $5 billion. I do want to point out that the half year, the first half of the year will have some variation to it because we are expecting one of our Yellow Pages books, in fact the Melbourne Book which is around about $100 million to be in the second half of this fiscal year, not the first half as it was last year. So I just want to alert you to that because as you try and figure out the half results or the expectations you need to know that.

Bottom line here really is we must invest to grow, win customers and lower our cost base to make room for a lower margin product mix world and to grow our EBITDA going forward. The benefits of this necessary investment will become obvious from 2012. Excluding any possible spectrum acquisition costs we foresee CapEx to sales of 14% over the medium term. It is important to note that the fiscal year '11 guidance is off our reported numbers, so the sales revenue of 24.8 billion and the EBITDA of 10.8 billion. Our guidance also assumes wholesale product price stability, over which we don't have a lot of control; no additional impairments to investment; and excludes any proceeds from sale of businesses. And you are aware we are in the middle of looking at the sale of Super fund for example.
So I'd like to thank you for listening to that and I'd now like to hand back to David, who will go through our future directions.

Thanks John. I think it was a very good summary. Okay, as I said at the beginning, the industry and Telstra are really going through some significant changes. But what I want to try and focus on now is it creates this unique opportunity for Telstra to really invest for the future and I want to try and give you some color about that this morning.

What we've got to do is put customers right at the center of what this company does every day. Very importantly John mentioned simplifying this business, taking all the complexity out of it so we truly can get a lower cost base going forward. We need to continue to focus on retaining and acquiring new customers, growing our customer base is very important and of course where to find new revenue streams as we go forward. You see this company has got to transform. It's got to move from being an engineering and technology led company to being a truly sales and market lead company. We need to keep our technology leadership but we must become truly sales and marketing led.

So I'm going to touch on about 4 areas this morning. Firstly, just touch again on some of the key achievements in 2010. So a little bit more about the inflection point we see in the industry, what's happening and why we're responding the way we are. A little bit about how we're going to respond and then talk a little bit more about the guidance. Now I'm only going to have a few moments to touch on each area. We do have an Investor Day scheduled for late September where we'll go in with more detail. A number of the senior execs will be able to talk about at that time exactly about some of the detailed initiatives under each of these initiatives.

Okay, let me start by just mentioning some of the significant achievements that really are quite remarkable really when you look at what the Telstra team has performed over the last 6 months. When I gave the half year results, I said how disappointed I was that we weren't able to bring a number of initiatives to market quickly enough. Well the second half was different. We really lifted the pace and we brought a large number of offers to market and we're seeing some of the early signs of momentum resulting from those initiatives.

On an adjusted basis we returned to modest growth in the second half and that was really driven by the mobile performance and of course IP performance which offset this enormous deterioration in PSTN. Now our sales results are improving and interest in our products, new products are high. So let's just go through a few of the strong results. I mean obviously Sensis, strong EBITDA growth. We soldmore than 300,000 bundles, 300,000 new wireless broadband customers. Mobile services revenue growth increased from 4.7% in the first half to 7.1% in the second half. And we're delighted that the new T-Hub and T-Box are experiencing strong interest and we've already sold 60,000 units ahead of our plan and that was as of last weekend. And of course we saw great sales results from the introduction of the iPhone 4 and we have also put new Pre-Paid cap plans into the market just last week.

So these results are encouraging. And top of this, the steps we began taking 15 months ago to improve customer satisfaction are starting to bite in the market. When I began as CEO, I described myself as an agent of the customer and I said it would not be quick or simple to reorient this company around our customers. However, I am pleased to report that throughout the year we began implementing a wide range of initiatives that are really starting to make a difference. Some of these included a new case management process for when people move home, a critical time when they make a decision on their telecommunication needs. We've introduced weekend appointments for our technicians. We've also put in new internal standards around responsiveness to queries, sales queries and complaints, which is starting to make this company more responsive. And of course as I mentioned we've put in new bundles and new pricing plans across a large name – range of products over the last 6 months.

So these changes are starting to make a difference. We're seeing TIO complaints come down by one third, though they're still too high. We have a very active program to manage all complaints and I am pleased to say in the monthly customer satisfaction survey we run, which is the customers giving us feedback about how we're going, we've seen an increase of 5% in the last 12 months which is very encouraging. Now, while we know there is still a lot more to do, we're started this journey and we're heading in the right direction.

Now another significant achievement was the NBN Financial Heads of Agreement that we signed last year. Now, I do want to stress, as you would expect we are nonpartisan when it comes to politics and we will constructively work with either side of government. So, we're making no comment about the policies of each party or the outcome of the federal election today. However, the non-binding Financial Heads of Agreement was a very important milestone. It's, you know it really was a tremendous amount of work that the team did to get to that point and it delivers a post-tax net present value of approximately $11 billion which includes around $9 billion consideration from NBN for copper decommissioning and infrastructure leasing and of course the $2 billion from the government in the form of other initiatives and avoided costs.

It's very important to understand, which was said before, the board will only take a proposal to shareholders that they believe will be in the best interest of our shareholders. I do want to clarify a few elements of this $9 billion. Between 40 and 50% of it will be for leasing our duct, exchange space, dark fiber and managed backhaul. The arrangement will be for 30 years or possibly more, so it provides for long-term certainty and we anticipate that the final decommissioning of copper will occur within 18 months of fiber being rolled out in any area. So, we are currently working on all the details, financial, legal and regulatory as we move forward towards definitive agreements.

For instance, we've agreed to supply and install optic fiber network infrastructure in Brunswick in Victoria which was a first release site for NBN Co. I do want to stress, there is still a lot of work ahead of us to get the agreement finalized and that we still need to get legislation passed, the ACCC approval must be also be obtained. But once these things have been achieved we'll be submitting this to our shareholders for a vote and which we expect to do in the first half of next calendar year.

So, we're pleased with the progress on the NBN negotiations. But as a last point around NBN. Whatever happens with NBN is irrelevant to what we need to do as a company. There are fundamental changes occurring in this industry that make it essential for Telstra to undergo significant change. So what I'd like to talk about now is a little bit about some of this change we're seeing in the market, what we call the inflection point, and give you some color to some of the comments John's already made.

We mentioned the accelerating decline in PSTN revenues. We've seen this reduction in fixed calls due to mobile substitution and of course that's being driven by capped plans primarily. We've seen a significant change in our product mix. We've seen the growth in mobile internet growing faster than fixed internet. Also we've seen this explosive use of data and video with little incremental revenue, and of course increasing price competition right across all the product categories but especially fixed broadband. And then lastly we're seeing growing infrastructure base competition partly due to government subsidized backhaul.

All of these forces are shifting our revenue mix towards lower margin products, so we need to take action. So we have the strategic choice, do we maximize short term cash returns by reducing costs and losing market share or do we bite the bullet and invest for longer term growth. Now we've decided that we must invest to maintain and acquire customers and to grow the business. We cannot continue to lose market share.

So we're going to take some bold steps. All of our actions will be consistent with the strategy that we outlined last October to satisfy our customers, invest in innovation and differentiation and of course find and realize new growth opportunities. So this next year, 2011, will be a transition year and we are going to focus on 4 key initiatives. Firstly, it's all going to be around customer satisfaction, serving our customers. We are going to simplify our business to reduce costs and of course to improve the customer experience. Also we are going to compete fairly but very aggressively to retain and acquire customers, leveraging our significant investments in network leadership that began 5 years ago. And of course invest in the long term business opportunities that we see.

So let me talk about just a little bit briefly now to give you some color on some of the things we are going to be investing in. Firstly customer satisfaction. We are going to continue to invest to improve customer service and satisfaction to our customers. This must become a key differentiator for Telstra. Over the next year we are going to do a number of things and I'm just going to mention a few quickly.

Firstly, we're going to introduce 24 by 7 contact center support. This is a new initiative that will commence on 14 September making Telstra the first full service telco to offer such a service. We are going to build an improved online capability, so customers can deal with Telstra online more often. We are also going to remove process bottlenecks that lead to complaints, so we improve our responsiveness to customer inquiries, issues and sales opportunities. We will also increase the customer satisfaction component in managers' performance bonuses so that we get the whole company focused on that. Now, customer service is now a fundamental and unifying theme for every part of Telstra, every part of Telstra, and it will be the cornerstone of our strategy going forward.

Secondly and very importantly we are going to simplify this business. We're going to drive savings that will improve customer service and satisfaction. We've begun on a 3-year journey to simplify our business and to deliver a lower sustainable cost base. Now, this is rather than an indiscriminate short term cost cutting program and this was considered that we must drive simplification into this business. As well as improving customer service, we will also improve productivity, change our channel mix and create a lower cost operating model.

This program is going to touch every part of this business and we've already started with the appointment of Robert Nason and we have teams working right across the business now. For example, you would have seen that we've reduced the Telstra executive ranks by more than 300 people. This will simplify our business, improve accountability, reduce management layers and make life simpler and faster for frontline staff to serve customers. You also would have seen another initiative, we brought together Telstra Country Wide and Telstra Consumer to make a more streamlined organization. Simplifying our business will be a huge project and we'll redefine all the key processes in the company and we will have much more to say about this at the Investor Day.

Thirdly, as I said in February, we must do what is necessary to stem market share decline and grow our customer base. This means competing more effectively and leveraging the incredible strengths we have in the Next G and Next IP networks. We need to acquire and retain customers which will lead to growth in our customer base and overall revenue. Now, we're going to do this in a number of different ways. We must invest in sales and marketing capability in 2011. We need to continue innovative and segmented based pricing. And of course you've seen over the last 6 months that we revised our prices on fixed and in mobile and broadband and postpaid and Pre-Paid. This will continue and we will do what is necessary to acquire and retain the best customers. This will require a significant investment in sales and marketing this year.

So, this is going to be a transition year, this is about competing and we are going to sell and market our differentiated products and services more aggressively. It is about leveraging the billions of dollars that we've invested for the benefit of our customers and our shareholders.

Let me give you a couple of examples. Our investment in Next G has delivered $787 million in wireless broadband over just 4 years. Wireless broadband penetration is approximately 17% and our customer base is now 1.65 million people, up 58% only a year ago. Smartphones also represent a huge opportunity for us. For example over the past year, the number of smartphone subscribers grew by 30% to 1.6 million and usage and ARPU grew as well. Thanks to our Next G network, Telstra is well positioned to take advantage of the accelerating migration to wireless communications.

In the next 12 months we will continue to drive our leadership in wireless speed and coverage. This will include introducing 42 megabits per second network download speeds peak, which will be a world first, and we are already trialing LTE. We believe that mobile can continue to grow at mid single digit levels for the next few years. That means in just 2 more years the mobile business may generate around $8 billion.

Let me give you another example, our Next IP network, which we will continue to invest in for market leadership. Our Next IP network has enabled us to double our IP access revenues in just 3 years. And as one of John's slide showed, the IP ARPU escalator, highlighting that about two thirds of our IP customers now buy managed WAN product from us and about 12% use IP telephony. Next IP also give us a large growth opportunity in markets adjacent to our traditional carriage business. One such market is network-absent services, which we are going to invest in as we go forward and we are very excited about cloud computing, both in terms of infrastructure-as-a-service, but also software-as-a-service, and this applies both to the business market and to the enterprise and government market. So we're moving up the value stair.

Let me now talk to the fourth initiative. We must make some significant investments to ensure our long term growth. A good example is how the digital future will impact a number of our key market segments. And we need to make the right investments. Let me just briefly mention a few of them. Firstly, the digital home which will offer consumers a way of integrating entertainment, information and communication services with their broadband connection. The very successful new T-Box and T-Hub IPTV are positive steps towards the digital home. Media, content and advertising also present exciting opportunities for us in the future.

Secondly, the digital business will integrate all data, video, voice and computing requirements for our small business customers, boosting productivity and improving services. Prices are going to be simple, easy to understand and services will be charged on a per-seat basis. We're very excited about this offering.

In the enterprise market, we are going to continue to build on our strategic offers, offers around application services all at a lower cost to improve productivity for those large customers. Then in the digital media space, Sensis is already undergoing significant investment in an exciting new set of online products for our Yellow Pages customers, which we think will really take us to a new level. Now you are going to hear more about this at Investor Day including the digital media opportunities at Sensis and we'll take you through them then.

Now let me turn to guidance and the investments necessary to achieve our strategic objectives. As John and I have already discussed, these investments will increase our cost base in 2011 because we are investing to grow our customer base. This will be a transition year, but these investments will be selective. They will be carefully targeted and they are going to be rigorously monitored to ensure they serve the long-term interests of customers and shareholders.

Let me you remind you once more why these investments are so essential at this time. The challenges we face are real.
